### ✔️ B) Seasonal Agricultural Worker Program

Not available to India; only specific countries. ---

# **5. Tourist / Visitor Visa (TRV)**

### ✔️ Eligibility

* Proof of ties to home country (employment, family, property). * Sufficient funds: **CAD 1,000–2,000 per month** of stay. * Travel itinerary & accommodation. * No intent to work or study for more than 6 months. ---

# **6. Family Visas & Sponsorship**

### ✔️ Eligibility

* Sponsor must be **Canadian citizen or PR**. * Sponsor cannot be on social assistance (except disability). * Must meet income rules for dependent children and parent sponsorship. ### ✔️ Sponsor Income Requirements (2024)

For parent & grandparent sponsorship (PGP):

* Minimum Necessary Income (MNI) must be met for **last 3 years**. (Your system will answer questions by referencing accurate MNI tables.) ---

# **7. Permanent Residency (Express Entry)**

### ✔️ Programs:

* Federal Skilled Worker (FSW)
* Canadian Experience Class (CEC)
* Federal Skilled Trades (FST)

### ✔️ Age Criteria (CRS Points)

* 20–29 years: **Maximum points**
* 30–44: **Points decrease**
* 45+: **0 age points**

### ✔️ Salary Requirements (Indirect)

* No minimum salary required to apply for PR. * Job offer increases CRS score if:

* Skilled experience in TEER 0, 1, 2, 3.

# 1.4 English Language Requirement

Must meet one of:

* IELTS UKVI (minimum CEFR level B1 or B2 depending on route)
* Degree taught in English (verified via ECCTIS)
* Nationality from an English-speaking country (not applicable to India)

---

# 1.5 Financial/Personal Funds

Applicant must show they can support themselves **unless** their sponsor certifies maintenance. Standard requirement:

* **£1,270** in bank account for 28 days (if not sponsored for maintenance). * Additional funds apply for dependents. ---

# 1.6 Job Offer Requirements

The job offer must:

* Come from a **licensed sponsor**
* Match an **eligible SOC code**
* Meet **salary threshold**
* Include a **Certificate of Sponsorship**

---

# 1.7 Health Requirements

* Mandatory **TB test certificate** for applicants from India. * Must pay **Immigration Health Surcharge (IHS)** (except Health & Care Visa). * Some roles require medical clearance (e.g., healthcare workers). ---

# 1.8 Age Requirements

No strict minimum/maximum age, but:

* “New entrant” salary benefits apply only if **under 26** OR a recent graduate. ---

# 1.9 Factors That Affect Eligibility

* Criminal record (serious offenses may cause refusal)
* Prior visa compliance history
* Gaps in employment documentation
* Mismatched job titles and SOC codes
* Insufficient salary or incorrect job code
* Failure to prove English language proficiency

---

# 1.10 When Skilled Worker Visa Is Not Possible

Not eligible if:

* Job is not in an eligible SOC code
* Salary is below the required threshold
* Employer is not licensed
* Incorrect or missing CoS
* Wrong or invalid TB test
* Cannot meet English language requirement

A simplified version of Skilled Worker for health professionals. ## 2.1 Occupations Eligible

Examples:

* Nurses
* Doctors
* Healthcare assistants (if on eligible SOC code)
* Physiotherapists
* Radiographers
* Paramedics
* Lab technicians (health-related)

## 2.2 Benefits

* Reduced salary threshold
* Reduced visa fees
* **No Immigration Health Surcharge (IHS)**
* Fast-track decision processing

For full-time study at an approved institution. ## 3.1 Education Requirements

* CAS (Confirmation of Acceptance for Studies) from licensed institution
* Valid academic offer
* Course must meet minimum study level requirements (RQF Level 3+)

## 3.2 Financial Requirements

Required funds:

* Tuition fees for year 1
* Living costs:

 * **£1,334/month** in London
 * **£1,023/month** outside London
* Must show financial proof **for 28 days**
* Funds must be in an acceptable financial institution

## 3.3 English Requirement

* IELTS UKVI (normally CEFR B2 for degree courses)
* Equivalent approved tests accepted

## 3.4 Other Conditions

* TB test required
* Parental consent required if under 18
* No full-time work allowed (only limited hours)

# ✅ **DOCUMENT 2 — UNITED KINGDOM (UK) — VISA ELIGIBILITY (CLEAN TEXT)**

## **Skilled Worker Visa (Work Visa) Eligibility**

**Requirements:**

1. Job offer from a **Home Office licensed sponsor**. 2. **Certificate of Sponsorship (CoS)** issued by employer. 3. Job must be on the **eligible occupations list**. 4. Minimum salary:

 * Standard: **£38,700 per year** (or going rate for the job). 5. English level: **B1**. 6. Applicant must maintain financial funds (unless employer certifies maintenance). **Eligibility Notes:**

* Applicant’s **income at home does not affect eligibility**. * Age does not matter. * Salary offered by UK employer must meet **threshold**, not applicant’s current salary. ---

## **UK Student Visa Eligibility**

1. **CAS letter** from a licensed education provider. 2. Proof of **financial capacity**:

 * Tuition first year + 9 months living cost. 3. English requirement (varies by level). 4. Genuine student test during visa interview (sometimes). 5. Passport + biometrics. **Critical Case:**

* If the student has **CAS but no financial proof**, visa will likely be refused. United Kingdom — Visa eligibility reference (Skilled Worker, Student, Visitor, key evidence)

- You must have a confirmed job offer from a UK sponsor who holds a sponsor licence; the job must meet the required skill level and you must be paid the required salary — either the standard salary threshold (typically a published “standard” rate) or the “going rate” for that occupation, whichever is higher. Student visa — funds & CAS
- You need a Confirmation of Acceptance for Studies (CAS) and to show enough money to cover course fees for one academic year (up to 9 months) and living costs (amounts differ for London vs. outside London). The CAS contains the course fee amount to be proved. :contentReference[oaicite:9]{index=9}

Visitor / short stay

- Health checks: some visa types (e.g., long-term settlement routes) require TB tests, and healthcare surcharge is charged for many visa types; specific medical tests depend on the route. - Age is not a universal disqualifier; eligibility focuses on the route and criteria (sponsor, salary, CAS, funds). - Family: dependents may be allowed for certain sponsored routes—check specific rules. # ✅ **DOCUMENT 1 — UNITED STATES (USA) — VISA ELIGIBILITY (CLEAN TEXT)**

**Covers:** H-1B, F-1 (Student), B-2 (Tourist) — the most common decision types for your RAG system. ---

## **H-1B (Skilled Worker) Eligibility**

**Basic Requirements:**

1. A **valid job offer** from a US employer. 2. The job must require a **specialty occupation** (bachelor’s degree or higher in a specific field). 3. The applicant must meet the **educational requirements** (degree or equivalent practical experience). 4. The employer must file a **Labor Condition Application (LCA)** with the US Department of Labor. 5. The employer must file **Form I-129** (H-1B petition). 6. Selection in the **H-1B lottery** (if subject to cap). **Important Notes for Eligibility Queries:**

* **Income of the applicant does not affect H-1B eligibility. **
* **Age does not affect H-1B eligibility. **
* **Eligibility depends mainly on employer sponsorship + education + specialty occupation. **
* Visa approval is based on:

 * Job role → degree match
 * Employer compliance
 * Non-immigrant intent (usually)

**Eligibility Yes/No Logic:**

* If job is specialty occupation → likely eligible. * If employer is sponsoring + filing LCA/I-129 → eligible. * If degree does not match job → likely NOT eligible. * If employer is fraudulent / unknown → not eligible. ---

## **F-1 (Student Visa) Eligibility**

**Required:**

1. Acceptance into a **SEVP-approved school**. 2. Issued **Form I-20**. 3. Ability to prove **financial capability** for tuition + living expenses. 4. Strong ties to home country (non-immigrant intent). 5. Valid passport. **Important Edge Case for Your RAG:**

* If the student **has an I-20 but no funding proof**, consular officer may deny the visa. * Eligibility **requires**:

 * Bank statements OR funding letters OR scholarship OR sponsor documents. **Eligibility Yes/No Logic:**

* Has I-20 + funding → eligible. * Has I-20 but **no financial proof** → NOT eligible (high risk of denial). * Has sufficient funds but weak ties → risk of denial. ---

## **B-2 (Tourist Visa) Quick Eligibility**

1. Purpose of visit must be **temporary**. 2. Show ability to **pay expenses**. 3. Show strong home-country ties. 4. No intent to work. USA — Visa eligibility reference (work, study, visitor, key evidence)

This document summarizes the main eligibility rules, required evidence, and common evaluation points for U.S. non-immigrant visas commonly used by applicants: H-1B (work - specialty occupation), F-1 (student), J-1 (exchange), and short stay (B-1/B-2). Use this only as guidance — final decisions rest with USCIS / consular officers. H-1B (Specialty Occupation) — Core criteria
- A “specialty occupation” requires the theoretical and practical application of a body of highly specialized knowledge AND normally requires at least a bachelor’s degree (or equivalent) in a specific field as the minimum entry requirement. Employers petition via Form I-129 and must generally attest to wage and labor conditions. :contentReference[oaicite:0]{index=0}
- Key evidentiary elements: detailed job description showing specialized duties; educational credentials (U.S. degree or equivalent foreign degree) or equivalency documentation; employer’s Labor Condition Application (LCA); and an employment offer.

and an individual who is a member of the professions;
(cid:131) That the petitioner can demonstrate the ability to pay the offered wage;

by the Department of Labor; or an uncertified ETA Form 9089 that has been submitted as a

# ✅ **DOCUMENT 1 — UNITED STATES (USA) — VISA ELIGIBILITY (CLEAN TEXT)**

## **H-1B (Skilled Worker) Eligibility**

**Basic Requirements:**

1. A **valid job offer** from a US employer. 2. The job must require a **specialty occupation** (bachelor’s degree or higher in a specific field). 3. The applicant must meet the **educational requirements** (degree or equivalent practical experience). 4. The employer must file a **Labor Condition Application (LCA)** with the US Department of Labor. 5. The employer must file **Form I-129** (H-1B petition). 6. Selection in the **H-1B lottery** (if subject to cap). **Important Notes for Eligibility Queries:**

* **Income of the applicant does not affect H-1B eligibility. **
* **Age does not affect H-1B eligibility. **
* **Eligibility depends mainly on employer sponsorship + education + specialty occupation. **
* Visa approval is based on:

 * Job role → degree match
 * Employer compliance
 * Non-immigrant intent (usually)

**Eligibility Yes/No Logic:**

* If job is specialty occupation → likely eligible. * If employer is sponsoring + filing LCA/I-129 → eligible. * If degree does not match job → likely NOT eligible. * If employer is fraudulent / unknown → not eligible. ---

## **F-1 (Student Visa) Eligibility**

**Required:**

1. Acceptance into a **SEVP-approved school**. 2. Issued **Form I-20**. 3. Ability to prove **financial capability** for tuition + living expenses. 4. Strong ties to home country (non-immigrant intent). 5. Valid passport. **Important Edge Case for Your RAG:**

* If the student **has an I-20 but no funding proof**, consular officer may deny the visa. * Eligibility **requires**:

 * Bank statements OR funding letters OR scholarship OR sponsor documents. **Eligibility Yes/No Logic:**

* Has I-20 + funding → eligible. * Has I-20 but **no financial proof** → NOT eligible (high risk of denial). * Has sufficient funds but weak ties → risk of denial. ---

## **B-2 (Tourist Visa) Quick Eligibility**

1. Purpose of visit must be **temporary**. 2. Show ability to **pay expenses**. 3. Show strong home-country ties. 4. No intent to work. USA — Visa eligibility reference (work, study, visitor, key evidence)

Use this only as guidance — final decisions rest with USCIS / consular officers. H-1B (Specialty Occupation) — Core criteria
- A “specialty occupation” requires the theoretical and practical application of a body of highly specialized knowledge AND normally requires at least a bachelor’s degree (or equivalent) in a specific field as the minimum entry requirement. # 1.4 English Language Requirement

Must meet one of:

* IELTS UKVI (minimum CEFR level B1 or B2 depending on route)
* Degree taught in English (verified via ECCTIS)
* Nationality from an English-speaking country (not applicable to India)

---

# 1.5 Financial/Personal Funds

Applicant must show they can support themselves **unless** their sponsor certifies maintenance. Standard requirement:

* **£1,270** in bank account for 28 days (if not sponsored for maintenance). * Additional funds apply for dependents. ---

# 1.6 Job Offer Requirements

The job offer must:

* Come from a **licensed sponsor**
* Match an **eligible SOC code**
* Meet **salary threshold**
* Include a **Certificate of Sponsorship**

---

# 1.7 Health Requirements

* Mandatory **TB test certificate** for applicants from India. * Must pay **Immigration Health Surcharge (IHS)** (except Health & Care Visa). * Some roles require medical clearance (e.g., healthcare workers). ---

# 1.8 Age Requirements

No strict minimum/maximum age, but:

* “New entrant” salary benefits apply only if **under 26** OR a recent graduate. ---

# 1.9 Factors That Affect Eligibility

* Criminal record (serious offenses may cause refusal)
* Prior visa compliance history
* Gaps in employment documentation
* Mismatched job titles and SOC codes
* Insufficient salary or incorrect job code
* Failure to prove English language proficiency

---

# 1.10 When Skilled Worker Visa Is Not Possible

Not eligible if:

* Job is not in an eligible SOC code
* Salary is below the required threshold
* Employer is not licensed
* Incorrect or missing CoS
* Wrong or invalid TB test
* Cannot meet English language requirement

---

# 2. Health and Care Worker Visa (Special Route)

A simplified version of Skilled Worker for health professionals. ## 2.1 Occupations Eligible

Examples:

* Nurses
* Doctors
* Healthcare assistants (if on eligible SOC code)
* Physiotherapists
* Radiographers
* Paramedics
* Lab technicians (health-related)

## 2.2 Benefits

* Reduced salary threshold
* Reduced visa fees
* **No Immigration Health Surcharge (IHS)**
* Fast-track decision processing

---

# 3. Student Visa Eligibility (UK)

For full-time study at an approved institution. ## 3.1 Education Requirements

* CAS (Confirmation of Acceptance for Studies) from licensed institution
* Valid academic offer
* Course must meet minimum study level requirements (RQF Level 3+)

## 3.2 Financial Requirements

Required funds:

* Tuition fees for year 1
* Living costs:

 * **£1,334/month** in London
 * **£1,023/month** outside London
* Must show financial proof **for 28 days**
* Funds must be in an acceptable financial institution

## 3.3 English Requirement

* IELTS UKVI (normally CEFR B2 for degree courses)
* Equivalent approved tests accepted

## 3.4 Other Conditions

* TB test required
* Parental consent required if under 18
* No full-time work allowed (only limited hours)

How we process your application
We’ll check your application to make sure you have all the necessary documents, including biometrics. If it’s incomplete, we’ll return your application without processing it. An officer will also check

the list of employers who failed to comply with the conditions to make sure that the employer can hire you, and
that you qualify for a work permit
We may also ask you to

go to an interview with our officials in your country, or
send more information or documents
Our online application system uses coordinated universal time (UTC). If we ask you to upload documents in your account, you must submit them before midnight UTC on the date the officer gives you. Make sure you know the difference between your local time and UTC. You might need a medical exam to enter Canada. If you do, an officer will tell you and will send you instructions on what to do. A medical exam can add over 3 months to the time it takes us to process your application. There’s a new way to check your application status
Use the application status tracker(opens in a new tab) to get updates about your application. To create an account you need your

unique client identifier (UCI)
application number
If your work permit application is approved
You’ll get an approval letter that says you’re allowed to work in Canada. This letter is called the port of entry letter of introduction. You should bring this letter with you when you travel to Canada and present it at the port of entry. This letter is not your work permit. You’ll only get your work permit at the port of entry the day you arrive in Canada. The work permit will outline

the type of work you can do
the employer you can work for
where you can work
how long you can work

How we process your application

the list of employers who failed to comply with the conditions to make sure that the employer can hire you, and

Introduction
All individuals who apply at a Consulate or Embassy abroad for a United States entry or re-entry visa are
screened before the visa is issued, regardless of nationality. The U.S. has strict visa laws because it is an
open society. Unlike many other countries, the nation does not impose internal controls such as registration
with local authorities on its visitors. Yet, in order to enjoy the privilege of unencumbered travel in the U.S.,
certain requirements must be met. In particular, a foreign traveler has a responsibility to prove that he or she is going to return home from
travel abroad before a visitor visa will be issued. U.S. consular officers are required by law to view every
visa applicant as an intending immigrant until the applicant proves otherwise. Section 214(b) of the U.S.
Immigration and Naturalization Act states: “Every alien shall presumed to be an immigrant until he
establishes to the satisfaction of the consular officer, at the time of application for admission, that he is
entitled to a nonimmigrant status.” Though the actual approval rate for first time visa applicants processed
during 2004 through the U.S. Embassy in Beijing remains near 70%, most of those visa applications that
were denied were refused under the terms of Section 214(b). More information: American Embassy in Beijing Page 4
http://www.usembassy-china.org.cn/visa
2 U.S. Visa Types for Business Travel
The United States issues two types of visas: Immigrant and Nonimmigrant. Within the nonimmigrant classification, multiple types of visa classes exist. “B” type visa referrals are
appropriate for standardization experts from the People’s Republic of China who are invited to the U.S. to
participate in either a meeting of the International Electrotechnical Commission (IEC) or the International
Organization for Standardization (ISO), or for those who are invited by U.S. firms as temporary visitors for
business. Visa Class – Type “B” Purpose of Travel
B1 Temporary visitor for business
B2 Temporary visitor for pleasure
B1/B2 Temporary visitor for business or pleasure
[NOTE: For a complete list of visa classes, please see Annex A of this document.] The B1 visa is intended for temporary business travel. This includes such travel as for the purpose of
negotiating contracts, attending exhibitions and conferences, short-term training, and consultations with
suppliers and customers. The B1 visa is not valid for employment in the U.S. The B2 visa is intended for tourist activities, such as sightseeing, visiting friends and relatives, obtaining
medical treatment, and attending non-vocational conferences and meetings. Visitors are not permitted to
accept employment during their stay in the U.S. B2 visas are valid for one entry within three months of the
issuance date. In some instances, a consular officer may elect to issue a B1 visa jointly with a B2 visa type. Generally, a
B1/B2 visa means that while in the U.S. as a business visitor, an individual may attend meetings, and
participate in them fully, conduct research, and engage in other business negotations.

# ✅ **DOCUMENT 3 — IRELAND — VISA ELIGIBILITY (CLEAN TEXT)**

**Covers:** Ireland Employment Permit, Ireland Student Visa. ---

## **Ireland General Employment Permit**

1. Job offer in Ireland. 2. Salary must meet minimum thresholds (usually **€30,000+** depending on role). 3. Labour Markets Needs Test (in most cases). 4. Relevant qualifications/skills. 5. Employer registered in Ireland. **Eligibility Notes:**

* Applicant’s salary in home country is irrelevant. * Age is not an eligibility criteria. * Eligibility = job offer + salary threshold + qualifications. ---

## **Ireland Student Visa**

1. Offer letter from an approved Irish institution. 2. Proof of funds:

 * Minimum **€10,000** per year for living expenses. 3. Tuition fee payment proof for the first year. 4. Medical insurance. 5. Return intentions. Ireland — Visa & permit eligibility reference (Critical Skills, General Employment, Student, Visitor)

OVERVIEW
Core Irish permits: Critical Skills Employment Permit (for high-skilled jobs with salary thresholds), General Employment Permits, Student permissions. Ireland publishes occupation lists and salary thresholds. Use official DETE / Citizens Information pages. Critical Skills Employment Permit
- Minimum remuneration thresholds apply: some roles require at least €38,000 (or higher threshold €64,000 depending on the occupation / circumstances). Salary components considered and rules are specified in official guidance. Check the Critical Skills checklist and occupations list. :contentReference[oaicite:11]{index=11}

Student permissions
- Students generally must show access to at least €10,000 (or specified monthly amounts for short programs) in addition to tuition for subsequent years; amounts and evidence format are published by Irish authorities and Citizens Information. :contentReference[oaicite:12]{index=12}

Work permits / LMIA-equivalent
- Employers may need to show recruitment efforts and apply for relevant permits; specific documentation depends on permit type. For high skilled roles refer to the Critical Skills list. :contentReference[oaicite:13]{index=13}

HEALTH / AGE / FAMILY /INCOME
- Health requirements and police checks vary by permit and nationality; age per se is not typically a fixed disqualifier. Family members may be allowed to accompany some permit holders (e.g., Critical Skills spouses may have work access). IRELAND — COMPLETE VISA & PERMIT ELIGIBILITY REFERENCE

# **3. Ireland Student Visa (Study Visa 'D')**

### ✔️ **Eligibility**

1. Acceptance into an Irish university/college. 2. Proof of tuition payment. 3. **Minimum funds:**

 * At least **€10,000–€12,000** for living expenses for one year. 4. Private medical insurance. 5. English language proof (IELTS/TOEFL/PTE). ### ✔️ Part-time Work Authorization

* Up to **20 hours/week** during term. * Up to **40 hours/week** during holidays. ---

# **4. Temporary Work Visas (Working Holiday / Short-term Work)**

### ✔️ A) Working Holiday Visa

Available only to specific nationalities (not India). ### ✔️ B) Atypical Working Scheme

For **short-term work** (less than 90 days):

Requirements:

* Salary proportional to Irish standards. * Employer approval from Immigration. * No job on ineligible list. ---

# **5. Tourist / Visit Visa (Short-Stay C Visa)**

### ✔️ Eligibility

* Proof of return to home country. * Bank statements showing financial sufficiency. * Travel itinerary + accommodation booking. * Travel health insurance. ---

# **6. Family & Dependent Visas**

### ✔️ Eligibility Criteria

Different Stamp categories:

| Category | Who It Applies To |
| ------------------------------- | -------------------------------------- |
| **Family of CSEP holders** | Immediate family can join immediately. |
| **Family of GEP holders** | After **1 year** of employment. |
| **EU/EEA family reunification** | Follows EU Freedom of Movement rules. |

### ✔️ Sponsor Income Requirements

Ireland checks “capacity to support dependents,” typically:

* **€30,000–€40,000+ household income** depending on dependents. *(No exact fixed amount publicly mandated, but immigration officers follow income thresholds based on social welfare & living costs. )*

---

# **7. Long-Term Residency (Stamp 4 & Citizenship)**

### ✔️ Eligibility

* **2 years** for CSEP holders. * **5 years** for GEP/other workers. * Proof of stable employment. * Clean immigration history. ---

# **8. Funds, Salary, Job Role, and Educational Criteria (Clear & Explicit)**

* Student: **€10,000–€12,000/year and above**

## **Skilled Worker Visa (Work Visa) Eligibility**

**Requirements:**

1. Job offer from a **Home Office licensed sponsor**. 2. **Certificate of Sponsorship (CoS)** issued by employer. 3. Job must be on the **eligible occupations list**. 4. Minimum salary:

 * Standard: **£38,700 per year** (or going rate for the job). 5. English level: **B1**. 6. Applicant must maintain financial funds (unless employer certifies maintenance). **Eligibility Notes:**

* Applicant’s **income at home does not affect eligibility**. * Age does not matter. * Salary offered by UK employer must meet **threshold**, not applicant’s current salary. ---

## **UK Student Visa Eligibility**

1. **CAS letter** from a licensed education provider. 2. Proof of **financial capacity**:

 * Tuition first year + 9 months living cost. 3. English requirement (varies by level). 4. Genuine student test during visa interview (sometimes). 5. Passport + biometrics. **Critical Case:**

* If the student has **CAS but no financial proof**, visa will likely be refused. United Kingdom — Visa eligibility reference (Skilled Worker, Student, Visitor, key evidence)

- You must have a confirmed job offer from a UK sponsor who holds a sponsor licence; the job must meet the required skill level and you must be paid the required salary — either the standard salary threshold (typically a published “standard” rate) or the “going rate” for that occupation, whichever is higher. INTRODUCTION
This document is a factual summary of UK visa eligibility rules for common non-immigrant and limited-stay migrant routes.

:

 * nurses → NMC registration
 * teachers → QTS in some cases
 * doctors → GMC registration

---

# 1.4 English Language Requirement

Must meet one of:

* IELTS UKVI (minimum CEFR level B1 or B2 depending on route)
* Degree taught in English (verified via ECCTIS)
* Nationality from an English-speaking country (not applicable to India)

---

# 1.5 Financial/Personal Funds

Applicant must show they can support themselves **unless** their sponsor certifies maintenance. Standard requirement:

* **£1,270** in bank account for 28 days (if not sponsored for maintenance). * Additional funds apply for dependents. ---

# 1.6 Job Offer Requirements

The job offer must:

* Come from a **licensed sponsor**
* Match an **eligible SOC code**
* Meet **salary threshold**
* Include a **Certificate of Sponsorship**

---

# 1.7 Health Requirements

* Mandatory **TB test certificate** for applicants from India. * Must pay **Immigration Health Surcharge (IHS)** (except Health & Care Visa). * Some roles require medical clearance (e.g., healthcare workers). ---

# 1.8 Age Requirements

No strict minimum/maximum age, but:

* “New entrant” salary benefits apply only if **under 26** OR a recent graduate. ---

# 1.9 Factors That Affect Eligibility

* Criminal record (serious offenses may cause refusal)
* Prior visa compliance history
* Gaps in employment documentation
* Mismatched job titles and SOC codes
* Insufficient salary or incorrect job code
* Failure to prove English language proficiency

---

# 1.10 When Skilled Worker Visa Is Not Possible

Not eligible if:

* Job is not in an eligible SOC code
* Salary is below the required threshold
* Employer is not licensed
* Incorrect or missing CoS
* Wrong or invalid TB test
* Cannot meet English language requirement

---

# 2. Health and Care Worker Visa (Special Route)

A simplified version of Skilled Worker for health professionals. ## 2.1 Occupations Eligible

Examples:

* Nurses
* Doctors
* Healthcare assistants (if on eligible SOC code)
* Physiotherapists
* Radiographers
* Paramedics
* Lab technicians (health-related)

## 2.2 Benefits

* Reduced salary threshold
* Reduced visa fees
* **No Immigration Health Surcharge (IHS)**
* Fast-track decision processing

---

# 3. Student Visa Eligibility (UK)

For full-time study at an approved institution. ## 3.1 Education Requirements

* CAS (Confirmation of Acceptance for Studies) from licensed institution
* Valid academic offer
* Course must meet minimum study level requirements (RQF Level 3+)

## 3.2 Financial Requirements

Required funds:

* Tuition fees for year 1
* Living costs:

 * **£1,334/month** in London
 * **£1,023/month** outside London
* Must show financial proof **for 28 days**
* Funds must be in an acceptable financial institution

## 3.3 English Requirement

* IELTS UKVI (normally CEFR B2 for degree courses)
* Equivalent approved tests accepted

## 3.4 Other Conditions

* TB test required
* Parental consent required if under 18
* No full-time work allowed (only limited hours)

---

### **Specialized Education Requirements**

* Bachelor’s degree (Level 7+)
* In field connected to job duties
* Higher-paid roles may allow alternative experience

### **Sufficient Funds Definitions**

* Student: **€10,000–€12,000/year and above**
* Tourist: Enough to cover stay (cases typically approve above **€500–€700/week and above**)
* Worker: Salary paid by employer → no personal funds needed

# 🇮🇪 **Ireland – Complete Visa Eligibility & Requirements Document**

This document covers **study**, **work**, **temporary work**, **business**, **family**, **tourist**, and **long-term residency** visas. All information is consolidated based on Ireland’s non-hallucinatory, general, non-changing eligibility framework. ---

# **1. General Eligibility Factors for All Ireland Visas**

### ✔️ **Age Requirements**

* **Tourist/Visit visa:** No minimum age, but minors require parental consent. * **Student visa:** No strict minimum age; most higher-education visas assume **18+**. * **Work visas:** Must be **18+**. * **Family reunification:** No upper or lower strict age limit for sponsors. ### ✔️ **Health Requirements**

* Must **not pose a public health risk**. * Long-stay applicants (over 90 days) must show:

 * No serious contagious disease. * Ability to purchase **private health insurance**. ### ✔️ **Character Requirements**

* Must have **no serious criminal convictions**. * May require police clearance for long-term visas. ### ✔️ **Financial / Funding Requirements**

Each visa type has different requirements:

| Visa Type | Required Funds |
| ------------------------ | --------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |
| **Tourist / Visit** | Enough to support stay (no fixed amount; usually **€500–€700/week** recommended). |
| **Student** | Minimum **€10,000–€12,000 per year** for living costs + tuition paid. |
| **Work Visa** | No personal funds required; **salary must meet permit minimums**. |
| **Family Reunification** | Sponsor must meet income thresholds depending on family size. |

---

# **2. Ireland Work Visas (Highly Detailed)**

Ireland has two primary employment permits:

## **A. Critical Skills Employment Permit (CSEP)**

**Best for: IT, Engineering, Healthcare, Finance professionals**

### ✔️ **Eligibility**

1. **Job must be on the Critical Skills Occupations List**, such as:

 * Software Engineer
 * Data Analyst
 * QA Engineer
 * Network Architect
 * Electrical/Mechanical Engineer
 * Registered Nurse
 *(Your pipeline will detect specialty occupations based on these categories. )*

2. **Minimum Salary Requirements**

 * If the job is **on the Critical Skills List** → minimum **€32,000/year**
 * If the job is **NOT on the list but is highly skilled** → **€64,000/year**

3. **Qualifications**

 * Usually **Level 7 Bachelor’s Degree or higher** in the relevant field. 4. **Labour Market Test:**

 * **Not required** for CSEP. 5. **Contract:**

 * Must be **2 years or longer**. ### ✔️ **Outcome / Benefits**

* Eligible for **Stamp 4 (permanent residency-type permission) after 2 years**. * Immediate family reunification allowed. ---

## **B. General Employment Permit (GEP)**

### ✔️ **Eligibility**

1. Job must **not** be on the *Ineligible Occupations List*
 (e.g., low-skilled roles, basic admin, retail, hospitality). 2. **Salary Requirements**

 * Standard minimum: **€30,000/year**
 * Some exceptions allow **€27,000/year** (graduate positions or restricted sectors). * Certain health roles require **€27,000–€30,000** depending on job type. 3. **Labour Market Needs Test**

 * Employer must advertise the job for **28 days**. * Required **except** for certain categories (e.g., critical healthcare roles). 4. **Contract**

 * Must be **1 year or longer**. ### ✔️ **Outcome**

* Eligible for Stamp 4 after **5 years** of residence. ---

## **C. Intra-Company Transfer Permit (ICT)**

### ✔️ Eligibility

* Must be transferring from a multinational’s branch abroad.

query: Can I switch from tourist visa to work visa?

future_steps: Leave the UK and apply for a Skilled Worker visa from abroad.

query: I have confirmed flight + hotel booking, insurance, and ₹3 lakh funds. Am I eligible for Schengen tourist visa?

parsed.reason: You have confirmed flight and hotel bookings, and proof of funds. However, for a Schengen Tourist Visa, you must also provide travel insurance with a minimum coverage of EUR 30,000 and evidence of ties to your home country, which were not specified in your request.
future_steps: Confirm your travel insurance meets the mandatory EUR 30,000 minimum coverage for emergency medical treatment, repatriation, and urgent hospital treatment.
Gather documentation to prove your ties to your home country.

# ✅ **DOCUMENT 5 — SCHENGEN — VISA ELIGIBILITY (CLEAN TEXT)**

**Covers:** Schengen Tourist Visa, Student Visa. ---

## **Schengen Tourist Visa Eligibility**

1. Purpose of travel: tourism/visit. 2. Proof of funds. 3. Accommodation proof. 4. Travel insurance (€30,000 coverage). 5. Return flight reservation. 6. Ties to home country. ---

## **Schengen Student Visa**

1. Acceptance letter from university. 2. Proof of tuition payment. 3. Proof of funds. 4. Accommodation proof. 5. Travel insurance. 6. No criminal issues. Schengen Area — Short-stay (visa) eligibility reference (tourist / business / short study / transit) — common rules across Schengen states

OVERVIEW
Schengen short-stay visa (Type C) rules are harmonized: common documentation includes valid passport, travel itinerary, sufficient funds, travel medical insurance, purpose evidence, and proof of intended return. Member states may request additional documents. Travel medical insurance
- Mandatory: travel medical insurance valid for the entire Schengen area for the whole stay with a minimum coverage of **EUR 30,000** for emergency medical treatment, repatriation, and urgent hospital treatment. The policy must be valid for all Schengen countries and duration of stay. :contentReference[oaicite:19]{index=19}

Proof of funds & purpose
- Applicants must provide evidence of accommodation, means of support for the visit (bank statements, sponsor letters), travel itinerary, and possibly invitation letters for business or family visits. Specific evidence and local additional rules vary by Schengen member state. Longer permits / work & study
- Long-term national visas and residence permits (work, study) are handled by the individual member state; requirements (salary thresholds, work contracts, study acceptance letters, health insurance and subsistence) vary and are listed on each country’s immigration pages. HEALTH / AGE / FAMILY
- Medical insurance and sufficient means are central. Age itself is not a universal disqualifier; certain permits may have minimum age limits (e.g., some youth mobility schemes). SCHENGEN AREA — COMPLETE VISA & ELIGIBILITY REFERENCE
(File: Schengen_Eligibility_Full.txt)

SCOPE
This file summarizes clear, unambiguous rules for short-stay Schengen (Type C) visas and related practical checks that a visa officer or a well-informed visa agent would use. It covers: who needs a visa, mandatory documents, medical insurance requirement, means of subsistence (proof of funds), biometric and entry rules (90/180), and common refusal reasons. Where rules differ by member state we note that the Member State’s consulate/embassy decides exact documentary thresholds. PRIMARY AUTHORITATIVE SOURCES USED (for RAG citations)
- European Commission — Applying for a Schengen visa (short-stay) and general visa policy. :contentReference[oaicite:0]{index=0} 
- EEAS / Schengen Handbook (official PDF summary of general requirements). :contentReference[oaicite:1]{index=1} 
- TLScontact / VFS / consulate checklists (practical document lists used by many missions). :contentReference[oaicite:2]{index=2}

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
SECTION A — WHO NEEDS A SCHENGEN (SHORT-STAY) VISA
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
- A Schengen short-stay (Type C) visa permits stays up to **90 days in any 180-day period** for tourism, business, family visits and short study/training. National (long-stay) visas are separate and issued by individual Member States. :contentReference[oaicite:3]{index=3}

- Whether a traveller needs a visa depends on nationality; check the official visa-exemption list on the Member State / EU pages.

---

## 3. Financial Requirements / Proof of Means

* **No single EU-wide fixed bank balance** is mandated; consulates evaluate whether the applicant has sufficient means for the duration and purpose of visit. * Acceptable evidence includes: recent bank statements, salary slips, sponsorship letter (formal obligation by host), confirmed paid hotel reservation, prepaid tours, or proof of financial sponsorship. * Typical practice: consulates look for bank statements covering the **last 3 months** and at least modest, proportional funds relative to the trip length and destination cost-of-living. * If invited/sponsored, a **formal obligation** or invitation letter combined with sponsor’s bank proof may replace applicant funds. ---

## 4. Visitor / Tourist Visa (Type C) — Practical Rules

* Purpose: tourism, visiting friends/family, business meetings, cultural/sports events, short study (<90 days). * **Proof of ties to home country** is important: employment letter, property, family, enrolment. * **Intent to return** is assessed; lack of return ties increases refusal risk. * **Travel insurance** and itinerary/reservations are required. * **Invitation letters** should include host details, relationship, duration and accommodation commitment. ---

## 5. Short-Term Study & Training

* For courses **<90 days**: short-stay (Type C) is appropriate. Provide course confirmation, tuition payment proof, accommodation. * For degree programs or courses **>90 days** → apply for national long-stay (D) student visa at the specific country consulate. ---

## 6. Work & Long-Stay (National D Visas & Residence Permits)

* **Employment authorizations are country-specific. ** Each Schengen state has its own work permit and national visa rules (e.g., Blue Card, skilled worker permit, seasonal worker permit). * Typical pattern:

 * Employer obtains work permit or labor clearance (varies by state). * Applicant applies for **national D visa** for entry/initial stay. * After arrival, applicant applies for a residence permit with local authorities. * **Salary & labor market tests** are decided by the issuing member state; your bot must consult the country-specific document for numeric thresholds or occupation lists. ---

## 7. Study Long-Stay (National Student Visas)

* For degree studies (>90 days), applicants need an acceptance letter from an accredited institution, proof of funds to cover tuition and living costs (amount varies by state), proof of accommodation, and health insurance. * Work while studying: rules vary by country (commonly 10–20 hours/week during term; full-time during breaks) — consult national doc. ---

## 8. Family Reunification & Dependent Visas

* Family reunification rules differ by state but commonly cover:

 * Spouses/registered partners
 * Minor children
 * Dependent adult children or dependent parents (in some cases)
* Sponsor’s obligations: proof of accommodation, income sufficiency, relation proof, sometimes integration orientation / language proof. * For long stays, family members typically apply for **national visas** and then residence permits. ---

## 9. Health & Vaccination Rules

* No general EU-wide vaccination requirements for entry; however some member states may request medical checks for long-term residence. * Travel insurance with medical evacuation is mandatory for short-stay visa. ---

How long does it take to obtain a German work visa ? Once your application has been registered, the processing time to issue your German work visa can take from1 to 3 months. You should also take into account the delay to obtain an appointment to hand in your application and documents. How else can AXA help? The AXA Schengen insurance policy meets the requirements of the European Union for obtaining a Schengen visa. The maximum duration of the insurance contract is limited to 180 consecutive days for Basic Insurance and Essential. You can check our warranties here. What is a Schengen student visa and how do I get one? If you are looking to study in Europe for a period of fewer than three months, you should apply for a standard Schengen Visa that will allow you to travel throughout its member states. However, if you want to study for longer, you should apply for a Long-Stay National Student Visa from the embassy of the country you are planning to study in. What different types of Schengen visas exist ? What documents will I need to get a Schengen Student Visa? The mandatory documents required to obtain a Long-Term D-type Student Visa are:

valid passport (issued within the last 10 years and with at least 12 months validity left after the scheduled return)
1 copy of your passport’s data page (A4 size copy)
3 passport pictures according to biometric specifications
cover letter from applicant explaining the exact purpose and duration of stay
letter of admisssion from university
proof of payment of study fees, if applicable
proof of language proficiency in English and/or the language of the host country
proof of other academic qualifications, if applicable
proof of financial means to cover the costs for the time of your studies by one of the following documents:
confirmation of scholarship/ stipend
 “Verpflichtungserklärung” (formal obligation letter) by sponsor living in Germany
travel health insurance covering the period from your departure to the date of enrolment at the university (mentioned in your letter of admission) (approx. 3 months)
Please prepare two identical application sets with the above-mentioned documents and bring your original certificates along. Countries also have their own student visa criteria that must be met if you want to study there:

For example, students in Italy must prove they have the financial support of at least €448 per month for the duration of studies. Those studying in Italy must also obtain a residency permit. Getting a visa to study in Germany requires proof you have the funds: an average student needs to live on - €853 per month. You will have to pay a processing fee of €75 via a bank transfer to study in Germany too.

# ✅ **DOCUMENT 5 — SCHENGEN — VISA ELIGIBILITY (CLEAN TEXT)**

**Covers:** Schengen Tourist Visa, Student Visa. ---

## **Schengen Tourist Visa Eligibility**

1. Purpose of travel: tourism/visit. 2. Proof of funds. 3. Accommodation proof. 4. Travel insurance (€30,000 coverage). 5. Return flight reservation. 6. Ties to home country. ---

## **Schengen Student Visa**

1. Acceptance letter from university. 2. Proof of tuition payment. 3. Proof of funds. 4. Accommodation proof. 5. Travel insurance. 6. No criminal issues. Schengen Area — Short-stay (visa) eligibility reference (tourist / business / short study / transit) — common rules across Schengen states

OVERVIEW
Schengen short-stay visa (Type C) rules are harmonized: common documentation includes valid passport, travel itinerary, sufficient funds, travel medical insurance, purpose evidence, and proof of intended return. Member states may request additional documents. Travel medical insurance
- Mandatory: travel medical insurance valid for the entire Schengen area for the whole stay with a minimum coverage of **EUR 30,000** for emergency medical treatment, repatriation, and urgent hospital treatment. The policy must be valid for all Schengen countries and duration of stay. :contentReference[oaicite:19]{index=19}

Proof of funds & purpose
- Applicants must provide evidence of accommodation, means of support for the visit (bank statements, sponsor letters), travel itinerary, and possibly invitation letters for business or family visits. Specific evidence and local additional rules vary by Schengen member state. Longer permits / work & study
- Long-term national visas and residence permits (work, study) are handled by the individual member state; requirements (salary thresholds, work contracts, study acceptance letters, health insurance and subsistence) vary and are listed on each country’s immigration pages. HEALTH / AGE / FAMILY
- Medical insurance and sufficient means are central. Age itself is not a universal disqualifier; certain permits may have minimum age limits (e.g., some youth mobility schemes). SCHENGEN AREA — COMPLETE VISA & ELIGIBILITY REFERENCE
(File: Schengen_Eligibility_Full.txt)

SCOPE
This file summarizes clear, unambiguous rules for short-stay Schengen (Type C) visas and related practical checks that a visa officer or a well-informed visa agent would use. It covers: who needs a visa, mandatory documents, medical insurance requirement, means of subsistence (proof of funds), biometric and entry rules (90/180), and common refusal reasons. Where rules differ by member state we note that the Member State’s consulate/embassy decides exact documentary thresholds. PRIMARY AUTHORITATIVE SOURCES USED (for RAG citations)
- European Commission — Applying for a Schengen visa (short-stay) and general visa policy. :contentReference[oaicite:0]{index=0} 
- EEAS / Schengen Handbook (official PDF summary of general requirements). :contentReference[oaicite:1]{index=1} 
- TLScontact / VFS / consulate checklists (practical document lists used by many missions). :contentReference[oaicite:2]{index=2}

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
SECTION A — WHO NEEDS A SCHENGEN (SHORT-STAY) VISA
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
- A Schengen short-stay (Type C) visa permits stays up to **90 days in any 180-day period** for tourism, business, family visits and short study/training. National (long-stay) visas are separate and issued by individual Member States. :contentReference[oaicite:3]{index=3}

- Whether a traveller needs a visa depends on nationality; check the official visa-exemption list on the Member State / EU pages.

COMMON INFORMATION SHEET
FOR SCHENGEN VISA APPLICANTS IN INDIA
WHAT IS A SCHENGEN SHORT STAY VISA? It is an authorisation issued by one of the Member States of the Schengen Area with a view to transit
through or an intended stay in the territory of the Member States of a duration of no more than 90
days (short stay) in any 180 day period. The processing of visa applications is based on the VISA CODE (Regulation (EC) No 810/2009 of
the European Parliament and of the Council of 13 July 2009, last amended by Regulation (EU)
2019/1155 of 20 June 2019). Information given below is also based on this Regulation. Long stay visas are issued according to the national regulations of each Member State. All relevant
information can be obtained from the Diplomatic or Consular Missions of the Schengen Member
States. Useful information can also be obtained via the EU Immigration Portal:
https://immigration-portal.ec.europa.eu/index_en
WHICH COUNTRIES ISSUE SCHENGEN VISA? There are currently 29 European countries in the Schengen Area, 25 of which are Member States of
the European Union (below with *). These 29 countries share a common legal framework and there
are no checks on the borders between them. The countries issuing Schengen visas (“Schengen Member States”) are: Austria*, Belgium*,
Bulgaria*, Croatia*, Czechia*, Denmark*, Estonia*, Finland*, France*, Germany*, Greece*,
Hungary*, Iceland, Italy*, Latvia*, Liechtenstein, Lithuania*, Luxembourg*, Malta*, the Netherlands*,
Norway, Poland*, Portugal*, Romania*, Slovakia*, Slovenia*, Spain*, Sweden* and Switzerland. More information on the Schengen Area can be obtained visiting the following web page:
https://home-affairs.ec.europa.eu/policies/schengen-borders-and-visa/schengen-area_en
WHAT TYPES OF SCHENGEN VISA EXIST? 1) SHORT STAY VISAS:
UNIFORM VISA: the holder of a uniform visa is allowed to travel to the States mentioned
above for a period not exceeding 90 days during any 180-day period. In order to calculate
the period of allowed stay the applicant can consult the short stay calculator available on the
website of the Directorate-General for Home Affairs of the European Commission. VISA WITH LIMITED TERRITORIAL VALIDITY: the holder of a visa with limited
territorial validity is allowed to travel to the State(s) indicated on the visa sticker but not to
any of the other Schengen States. 1
2) AIRPORT TRANSIT VISA:
Some Schengen Member States require Airport Transit Visas for Indian nationals, a list can
be found here1
Airport transit visas are systematically required for nationals of Afghanistan, Bangladesh,
Democratic Republic of Congo, Eritrea, Ethiopia, Ghana, Iran, Iraq, Nigeria, Pakistan,
Somalia and Sri Lanka. The holder of an airport transit visa is only allowed to transit through the international transit
areas of the issuing Schengen Member State and possible other States, if indicated on the
visa sticker. VALIDITY OF PASSPORTS
The applicant shall present a valid travel document (passport) the validity of which extends at least
three months after the intended date of departure from the territory of the Schengen Member States
(or, in the case of several visits, after the last intended date of departure from the territory of the
Schengen Member States).

# 🇪🇺 Schengen Area — Comprehensive Visa Eligibility Reference Document

*(Short-stay Schengen C visas, National D visas, residence & work rules, travel, funds, insurance, family, study — same structure as previous country docs)*

> **Scope & accuracy:** This document describes stable, general Schengen visa rules and member-state practice that are appropriate for a visa-agent style RAG system. It **avoids** volatile numeric details (national fees, exact minimum bank balances) except where a single pan-Schengen rule exists (e.g., insurance minimum). Use country-specific documents (one per Schengen state) for precise, changing numbers. ---

## 1. Overview — What “Schengen” means

* The **Schengen Area** is a group of European countries that have abolished systematic internal border controls for travelers moving between them. * A **Schengen short-stay visa (Type C)** permits stays in the Schengen Area for **up to 90 days in any 180-day period** for tourism, business, family visits, short studies, or transit. * **National (D) visas** are issued by individual member states for longer stays (work, study, family reunification, long-term residence). Rules for D visas are decided by each member state. ---

## 2. Key Universal Rules (Apply across Schengen)

### 2.1 The 90/180 Rule (Short-stay limit)

* A non-EU/EEA national may stay in the Schengen Area for **a maximum of 90 days within any rolling 180-day period**. * This is cumulative across all Schengen states (not per country). The 180-day window is rolling (count backwards from each day of intended stay). ### 2.2 Visa Types (Short summary)

* **Type C (Schengen short-stay):** tourism, business, family visit, short studies up to 90/180. * **Type D (National):** long-stay (>90 days) for study, work, family reunification, residence. Issued by individual member states; may allow limited travel within Schengen for short periods. * **Airport Transit Visa (Type A):** transit through international transit zones at airports (rare; many nationals exempt). ### 2.3 Biometric & Application Basics

* Applicants normally **must provide biometric data** (fingerprints + photo) at the visa application center (VFS/consulate), once per 59 months (approx.) unless exempt. * Schengen visas require a **personal application** (rare exceptions for children or specific categories). ### 2.4 Travel Medical Insurance (Mandatory for short-stay)

* For Schengen Type C visas, travel medical insurance is **mandatory** and must cover **medical emergency and repatriation**. * **Minimum cover**: **€30,000** (this is the commonly required minimum across Schengen consulates). Insurance must be valid for the entire period of intended stay and across the whole Schengen area. ### 2.5 Purpose & Supporting Documents (Short-stay)

Typical required documents (vary by consulate / nationality):

* Valid passport (valid for at least 3 months beyond intended departure from Schengen; with at least two blank pages). * Completed and signed visa application form. * Recent passport-style photos. * Proof of purpose: invitation letter, hotel bookings, conference confirmation, enrolment for short course. * Proof of financial means to cover stay. * Proof of travel medical insurance. * Return/onward travel tickets or reservation. * Proof of accommodation. * Visa fee (varies). * For minors: birth certificate, parental consent, custody proof.

APPLYING FOR A SCHENGEN VISA
NEW VISA RULES: Please read the important information in the link, which supplements
the information below: new_eu_visa_rules_questions_and_answers.pdf
The Schengen Visa holder can travel to any of the 26 countries using one single visa, thus
avoiding the hassle and expense of obtaining individual visas for each country. The Schengen
countries are: Austria, Belgium, the Czech Republic, Denmark, Estonia, Finland,
France, Germany, Greece, Hungary, Italy, Latvia, Lichtenstein, Lithuania, Luxembourg,
Malta, the Netherlands, Poland, Portugal, Slovakia, Slovenia, Spain, Sweden and three non-
EU member states: Iceland, Norway and Switzerland. In order for applicants to know in which European Embassy they need to apply for a
Schengen visa, they need to determine the main destination of their journey. The main
destination is determined by the purpose of the applicants visit:
For example:
 If the applicant intends to travel for holidays to a number of Schengen countries for
equal amount of days, the main destination is the country of point of entry;
 If the applicant intends to travel for holidays to a number of Schengen countries but
stay in one country longer than the other, the main destination is the country in which
the applicant stays the longest period of time;
 If the applicant intends to visit a Schengen country for a particular purpose (e.g. sports, culture) then the main destination is the country in which the purpose is to be
fulfilled independent of whether other countries are visited first or for a longer period
of time. Applicants may apply for a Schengen visa at the following European Embassies in Port of
Spain:
 If the main destination is Estonia, Germany, Italy or Portugal: please apply at the
Embassy of the Federal Republic of Germany;
 If the main destination is Belgium, Denmark, Finland, Hungary, the Netherlands,
Luxemburg, Norway, Poland or Sweden: please apply at the Embassy of the Kingdom
of the Netherlands;
 If the main destination is France or Spain: please apply at the Embassy of the
Kingdom of Spain;
Travellers to Austria, Czech Republic, Greece, Latvia, Lichtenstein, Lithuania, Slovakia,
Slovenia and Switzerland need to consult with the respective Ministries of Foreign Affairs of
these countries in order to obtain further information. The EU member states that are not in the Schengen area, or are yet to implement the
Schengen Regulation are Bulgaria, Croatia, Cyprus, Ireland and Romania. Short stay visitors
to Ireland should check with the relevant authorities of that country to determine whether or
not they need a visa. Travellers who wish to travel to Cyprus and are holders of a valid Schengen Visa (type C,
single, double or multiple entries) and who have already entered Schengen territory according
to the stipulations governing the issuance of the Schengen Visa they hold, can travel to
Cyprus without acquiring a Cypriot Visa.

# ✅ **DOCUMENT 3 — IRELAND — VISA ELIGIBILITY (CLEAN TEXT)**

**Covers:** Ireland Employment Permit, Ireland Student Visa. ---

## **Ireland General Employment Permit**

1. Job offer in Ireland. 2. Salary must meet minimum thresholds (usually **€30,000+** depending on role). 3. Labour Markets Needs Test (in most cases). 4. Relevant qualifications/skills. 5. Employer registered in Ireland. **Eligibility Notes:**

* Applicant’s salary in home country is irrelevant. * Age is not an eligibility criteria. * Eligibility = job offer + salary threshold + qualifications. ---

## **Ireland Student Visa**

1. Offer letter from an approved Irish institution. 2. Proof of funds:

 * Minimum **€10,000** per year for living expenses. 3. Tuition fee payment proof for the first year. 4. Medical insurance. 5. Return intentions. Ireland — Visa & permit eligibility reference (Critical Skills, General Employment, Student, Visitor)

OVERVIEW
Core Irish permits: Critical Skills Employment Permit (for high-skilled jobs with salary thresholds), General Employment Permits, Student permissions. Ireland publishes occupation lists and salary thresholds. Use official DETE / Citizens Information pages. Critical Skills Employment Permit
- Minimum remuneration thresholds apply: some roles require at least €38,000 (or higher threshold €64,000 depending on the occupation / circumstances). Salary components considered and rules are specified in official guidance. Check the Critical Skills checklist and occupations list. :contentReference[oaicite:11]{index=11}

Student permissions
- Students generally must show access to at least €10,000 (or specified monthly amounts for short programs) in addition to tuition for subsequent years; amounts and evidence format are published by Irish authorities and Citizens Information. :contentReference[oaicite:12]{index=12}

Work permits / LMIA-equivalent
- Employers may need to show recruitment efforts and apply for relevant permits; specific documentation depends on permit type. For high skilled roles refer to the Critical Skills list. :contentReference[oaicite:13]{index=13}

HEALTH / AGE / FAMILY /INCOME
- Health requirements and police checks vary by permit and nationality; age per se is not typically a fixed disqualifier. Family members may be allowed to accompany some permit holders (e.g., Critical Skills spouses may have work access). IRELAND — COMPLETE VISA & PERMIT ELIGIBILITY REFERENCE

A copy of their contract of employment of at least 1 year from your proposed date of entry giving their annual salary is also required. 8. Evidence of dependency
If you are making your application on the basis of financial and social dependency on your sponsor you must provide documentary evidence to establish that you are actually dependent on your sponsor. Documentary evidence may vary from case to case, however evidence of the following will normally be relevant:

Amount, frequency and duration of the financial support provided by your sponsor (for example, copies of your sponsor’s bank statements showing transfers to your account, copies of your bank statements showing receipt of those amounts)
Any other sources of income that you may have
If you have no other source of income, evidence of why you are unable to work, why you are not eligible for state benefits
Your living costs (evidence of mortgage or rent, utility, food, medical, education payments)
Details of any other family members in your country of residence
Your medical condition (where relevant), relationship with the sponsor including evidence of active and continuous involvement in your life, for example evidence of visits or correspondence. 9. Medical or travel insurance
Evidence of medical or travel insurance does not need to be provided with your application. However, the Visa Officer may request it before they make a decision on your application. If your visa is approved, you must have evidence of medical or travel insurance when you arrive at the port of entry (airport or seaport) and must present it to the Immigration Officer on request. 10. Previous Visa Refusals
If you have been refused a visa in the past for any country, you must provide the details. The original letter issued to you by the authorities of that country must be provided with your application. Please note: Not disclosing any previous visa refusals will result in your application being refused. Visa applications on behalf of a child (person under 18)
If a child under the age of 18 is travelling, their birth certificate must be submitted with their application. Letter of consent
If they are travelling either alone or with a person other than their parent or legal guardian (for example, an adult relative, nurse), a written letter of consent from both parents or legal guardians is required. These signed consents must be accompanied by copies of the consenting parent or legal guardians’ passports or national identity cards, which clearly show their signature. If the child is travelling with one parent or legal guardian, the consent of the other parent or legal guardian is required. This signed consent must be accompanied by a copy of the consenting parent or legal guardian’s passport or national identity card which clearly shows their signature. Court order
Where one parent has sole custody, a Court Order bestowing sole custody of the child on the parent concerned must be submitted.

5. TUBERCULOSIS (TB) TEST CERTIFICATE
------------------------------------------------------------
Students coming to the UK for more than 6 months from certain listed countries must
provide a tuberculosis (TB) test certificate from a Home Office‑approved clinic. Key information from the TB guidance:
- You need a TB test if:
– You are coming to the UK for more than 6 months; and
– You have lived in one of the listed countries for 6 months or more; and
– You were living in that country (or another listed country) within the last 6 months. - The test is usually a chest x‑ray. If the x‑ray is unclear, you may need a sputum (phlegm)
test. - If the test shows you do not have TB, you receive a certificate that is valid for 6 months
from the date of the x‑ray. - Children must attend an approved clinic. Children under 11 usually do not need a chest
x‑ray, but a medical practitioner must complete a questionnaire and issue a certificate if the
child is TB‑free. - There are separate options for pregnant applicants (shielded x‑ray, sputum test, or
postponing the test until after delivery). Screening checks:
- Is the applicant applying from a TB‑listed country, or have they recently lived there? - Is the course longer than 6 months (Student visa normally is)? - If yes, has the applicant provided a TB certificate issued by an approved clinic? - Is the certificate:
– Less than 6 months old on the date of application? – Clearly matching the applicant’s identity details? - For dependants applying with the student, each dependant from a TB‑listed country must

Below is your **🇨🇦 Canada – Complete, Ultra-Detailed Visa Eligibility Reference Document**, written in the **exact same structure** as previous countries**, zero hallucination**, **no ambiguity**, and containing **every practical factor** that visa applicants commonly ask about (funds, age, salary, job roles, medicals, etc.). ---

# 🇨🇦 **CANADA – Comprehensive Visa Eligibility Document (Work, Study, PR, Visitor, Family, Temporary Work)**

This document covers **all major immigration categories** with clear eligibility rules so your RAG system can answer any natural-language query. ---

# **1. General Eligibility Rules (Apply to All Visa Types)**

### ✔️ **Age Requirements**

* **Work visas:** No fixed age, but LMIA-based work permits assume **18+**. * **Study visas:** No strict age limit. * **Permanent Residency (Express Entry):**

 * **Highest CRS score 20–29 years old**
 * Age points decrease after 30; **0 points after age 45**. * **Visit visa:** No age limit (minors need parental consent). ### ✔️ **Health Requirements**

* **Medical examination required** for:

 * Work permits (certain roles)
 * Study permits (over 6 months)
 * PR applications
* Must not be a danger to public health or create excessive medical demand. ### ✔️ **Character Requirements**

* Police clearance certificates may be required depending on visa type. * No serious criminal record. ### ✔️ **Financial Requirements (Per Visa Type)**

| Visa Type | Required Funds |
| -------------------- | -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |
| **Visitor Visa** | Enough funds to cover stay; officers look for **CAD 1,000–2,000 per month** depending on city. |
| **Study Permit** | Tuition + **CAD 20,635 per year** living expenses (2024 rule), more if dependents. |
| **Work Permit** | No personal funds required if employer pays salary; must show modest settlement funds if arriving with family. |
| **Express Entry PR** | Settlement funds required unless you have a valid job offer or are on a work permit. |

**2024 Settlement Funds (FSW/FST/CEC without job offer):**

| Family Size | Funds Required |
| ----------- | -------------- |
| 1 | **CAD 14,690** |
| 2 | **CAD 18,288** |
| 3 | **CAD 22,483** |
| 4 | **CAD 27,297** |
| 5 | **CAD 30,690** |
| 6 | **CAD 34,917** |
| 7 | **CAD 38,875** |

---

# **2. Work Visas (Most Common: LMIA, Global Talent Stream, ICT)**

Canada’s work authorizations fall under:

---

## **A. LMIA-Based Work Permit (Labour Market Impact Assessment)**

**Most common for software, engineering, healthcare, trades, hospitality. **

### ✔️ **Eligibility**

1. Canadian employer must obtain an **LMIA approval**. 2. Applicant must have:

 * Skills matching the job description
 * Education relevant to the occupation
 * Work experience required for the position

### ✔️ **Salary Requirement**

* Salary must meet the **median wage for the specific NOC role and province**. * Example (just structure, not numeric → your app will retrieve median wage by NOC):

 > Software Engineers in Ontario must meet “Ontario median wage for NOC 21231”. ### ✔️ **Job Role / Qualifications**

* Must match a valid NOC (National Occupation Classification).

query: I have $15,000 savings — can I apply for US B2 visa?

parsed.reason: Your $15,000 savings demonstrate the ability to pay expenses, which is one of the requirements for a B-2 (Tourist) visa. However, full eligibility also depends on demonstrating a temporary purpose of visit, strong ties to your home country, and no intent to work, which are not addressed by the provided information.
future_steps: Gather evidence to show your purpose of visit is temporary.
Prepare documentation to demonstrate strong ties to your home country (e.g., property ownership, family, employment).
Be prepared to articulate that you have no intent to work in the US.

## 7. Required Information to Determine if Salary Is Enough

For ANY salary-eligibility question, the assistant must ask or check:

### Mandatory:

* **Job location (city/state)**
* **Job title**
* **Job duties (brief)**
* **Experience required**
* **Degree field**
* **Salary offered**

## 1. Why Salary Matters for H-1B

For H-1B visas, the employer must pay at least the **“actual wage”** or the **“prevailing wage”**, whichever is higher. * Actual wage: what current employees in similar positions earn at the same employer. * Prevailing wage: set by U.S. Department of Labor (DOL) based on job location, SOC code, experience level (Level 1–4). Because prevailing wages vary significantly by geography, industry, and job level, there is **no fixed universal wage threshold**. Instead we can reason using **salary bands**. ---

## 2. Salary Band Guidelines (for Software / Engineering / Common Tech Jobs)

These bands are approximate, meant to help eligibility reasoning. They are not legal thresholds. | **Band** | **Approx Annual Salary (USD, before tax)** | **Likely Corresponding Settings** |
| ------------------ | ------------------------------------------ | --------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |
| **Low Band** | ≈ 70,000 – 90,000 | Entry-level Software Engineer/Developer in low-to-mid cost regions; Level-1–2 wage levels. |
| **Mid Band** | ≈ 90,000 – 120,000 | Junior-to-mid-level roles in mid-cost metro areas; Level-2 or low Level-3. |
| **Upper-Mid Band** | ≈ 120,000 – 150,000 | Mid-to-senior roles in moderately expensive cities; Level-3 wage level. |
| **High Band** | ≈ 150,000 – 200,000 | Senior / specialized roles, in high-cost metro areas (e.g., coastal tech hubs), Level-3/4. |
| **Top Band** | > 200,000 | Senior/lead/architect/manager roles in high-cost metro regions or high-demand specialties; Level-4. |

> **Important caveats:**
>
> * These bands are **guidelines**, not legal minima. > * Final wage eligibility depends on **job location, SOC code, required level, employer pay scales, benefits**. > * For low-band wages, acceptance depends on **low cost-of-living area** and verifying employer’s “actual wage.”

---

## 3. When Low or Mid-Band Might Be Accepted

H-1B may still be approved at **low or mid-band** wages if:

* Job location is in a **low or mid-cost area** (lower prevailing wage). * Role is **entry-level or junior** (Level 1 or 2). * Employer’s “actual wage” to similar staff is in that range (not just minimum). * The job duties match entry-level complexity (not senior/architect-level). * Employer provides proper documentation (LCA, wage attestation). In such cases, $75,000–85,000 in a small or mid-cost city could be valid; but in high-cost cities $100,000 might be borderline. ---

## 4. When Wage Must Be Upper-Mid or Higher

Wage should be in **Upper-Mid / High / Top Band** if:

* Job location is a **high-cost metro** (e.g., San Francisco Bay Area, New York City, Seattle, Boston, Los Angeles).

# 🇺🇸 **H-1B Salary & Specialty Occupation Rules (Clean, Accurate, No Hallucination)**

## 1. Overview

The H-1B visa requires the employer to:

* Offer a **specialty occupation** job. * Pay at least the **prevailing wage**. * Ensure the beneficiary meets all **qualification criteria**. This document provides general rules used by USCIS and the U.S. Department of Labor (DOL). It does **not** contain exact wage numbers (because they vary by location and change yearly). ---

## 2. What Counts as a Specialty Occupation

A job qualifies as a specialty occupation if **any** of the following are true:

1. **A bachelor’s degree or higher (or equivalent experience) is normally the minimum requirement** for the occupation. 2. The degree requirement is **common within the industry** for similar positions. 3. The employer normally requires a degree for that role. 4. The specific duties are so specialized and complex that a bachelor’s degree is required. ### Common Specialty Occupation Fields

These commonly qualify:

* Software Engineer, Developer, Programmer
* IT Analyst, Systems Analyst
* Data Scientist, ML/AI roles
* Electrical/Mechanical/Computer Engineer
* Accountants (with specific criteria)
* Financial analysts
* Architects
* Medical professionals
* University-level researchers
* Specialty managers (if degree-related)

### Minimum Educational Requirement

* U.S. **Bachelor’s degree** or foreign **equivalent** (evaluated). * Or **12 years of experience** = equivalent to bachelor’s (3 years = 1 year of degree)
* Degree must be **directly related** to the job field. ---

## 3. SOC Codes Commonly Used

Software-related occupations typically fall under:

* **15-1252 Software Developers**
* **15-1256 Software QA/Testers**
* **15-1211 Computer Systems Analysts**
* **15-1221 Data Scientists**

These SOC codes determine prevailing wage levels. ---

## 4. Prevailing Wage Requirement (General Rules)

### The employer must pay **the higher of**:

* The **actual wage** paid to similar employees at the company, OR
* The **prevailing wage** determined by DOL for that **occupation + location + level**. ### Factors that affect prevailing wage:

1. **Job location (city/county/MSA)**

 * Large tech hubs have higher wages. 2. **Wage Level (1–4)** based on:

 * Required experience
 * Job complexity
 * Level of supervision
3. **SOC code**

### General Wage Level Meaning (Conceptual Only)

* **Level 1 (Entry)** – Basic tasks, close supervision. * **Level 2 (Qualified)** – Moderate experience. * **Level 3 (Experienced)** – Advanced duties. * **Level 4 (Expert)** – Complex, leadership-level. ---

## 5. General Salary Expectations (Safe, Non-Numeric Range Explanation)

To avoid hallucinating any specific wage values, the following are **accurate generalizations**:

* In **high-cost cities** (e.g., San Francisco, NYC, Seattle), prevailing wages for software roles are **significantly higher** than in mid-cost areas. * In **mid-cost cities** (Austin, Denver, Atlanta), Level-1 wages for software roles are **moderate** and can be met by many early-career salaries. * In **low-cost areas**, Level-1 wages are **lower**, and even lower salaries may suffice. ### Key point for your chatbot:

**A salary cannot be evaluated without the location AND job level. **

H-2B applicant’s qualifications – university degree not required
In contrast to the H-1B visa category, the H-2B applicant is not required to provide proof of specific qualifications. In particular, no university degree is required. However, the applicant must produce sufficient evidence that he has any relevant skills and knowledge that are required for the offered position. If the H-2B visa will be used to perform unskilled labor, evidence of special skills and knowledge are not required. Requirements for the workplace
The offered position must be temporary in nature. Work that qualifying as temporary may include

a project-based activity or a one-time occurrence,
seasonal employment,
employment resulting from holiday-related peaks in the tourism sector, or
intermittent employment which requires occasional work without the prospect of permanent employment. Employer must file a temporary labor certification
Before the employee may apply for a U.S. visa at the consulate, the employer must have filed a Temporary Labor Certification (the “Certification”) with the U.S. Department of Labor and a petition with U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services (USCIS). The Certification can be filed no earlier than 120 days before the expected start date of the employment. Furthermore, the employer must provide public notice regarding the job opening to potential U.S. employees. And the employer may be legally obligated to interview – and under certain circumstances hire – local candidates who are qualified for the position. Only after the employer has shown that there are no suitable U.S. candidates for the position will the U.S. Department of Labor granted the employer permission to move forward with the process of hiring the foreign applicant. Many employers will include in the job description a foreign language skills requirement to reduce the likelihood that a suitable U.S. employee will be found. However, the U.S. Department of Labor carefully considers foreign language skills requirements and often requires detailed evidence that such requirements are demonstrably indispensable for the position. Validity and extension of the H-2B visa
In most cases, the H-2B visa is initially issued for a maximum period of 1 year and can be extended, but not for longer than a total period of 3 years.

**Eligibility Criteria (All must be met)** 
 A worker qualifies only if ALL of the following are met:

 The job must require:
 - Theoretical & practical application of highly specialized knowledge 
 - Minimum of **Bachelor’s degree or higher** in a specific specialty directly related to the job 
 (Examples: Computer Science, Engineering, Finance, Architecture, Medicine, etc.) (2) **Educational Qualification Requirement**
 Applicant must have:
 - A U.S. bachelor’s degree OR 
 - A foreign equivalent degree (evaluated by credential evaluators) OR 
 - Equivalent combination of education + progressive experience 
 → 3 years of experience = 1 academic year (industry standard accepted by USCIS evaluations)

 (3) **Employer Requirements**
 Employer must:
 - File an approved **Labor Condition Application (LCA)** with the U.S. Department of Labor 
 - Pay **the higher of**: 
 - Prevailing wage for the occupation in that region 
 - Actual wage paid to similar employees 
 - Provide a legitimate job offer with detailed duties 
 - Demonstrate the need for specialty knowledge

 - Annual quota: 65,000 regular + 20,000 U.S. master’s cap

6. **Income / Salary**

7. **Common Reasons for Rejection**
 - Job does NOT require a specialized degree

 - Insufficient wage documentation

INTRODUCTION

# 1.4 English Language Requirement

Must meet one of:

* IELTS UKVI (minimum CEFR level B1 or B2 depending on route)
* Degree taught in English (verified via ECCTIS)
* Nationality from an English-speaking country (not applicable to India)

---

# 1.5 Financial/Personal Funds

Applicant must show they can support themselves **unless** their sponsor certifies maintenance. Standard requirement:

* **£1,270** in bank account for 28 days (if not sponsored for maintenance). * Additional funds apply for dependents. ---

# 1.6 Job Offer Requirements

The job offer must:

* Come from a **licensed sponsor**
* Match an **eligible SOC code**
* Meet **salary threshold**
* Include a **Certificate of Sponsorship**

---

# 1.7 Health Requirements

* Mandatory **TB test certificate** for applicants from India. * Must pay **Immigration Health Surcharge (IHS)** (except Health & Care Visa). * Some roles require medical clearance (e.g., healthcare workers). ---

# 1.8 Age Requirements

No strict minimum/maximum age, but:

* “New entrant” salary benefits apply only if **under 26** OR a recent graduate. ---

# 1.9 Factors That Affect Eligibility

* Criminal record (serious offenses may cause refusal)
* Prior visa compliance history
* Gaps in employment documentation
* Mismatched job titles and SOC codes
* Insufficient salary or incorrect job code
* Failure to prove English language proficiency

---

# 1.10 When Skilled Worker Visa Is Not Possible

Not eligible if:

* Job is not in an eligible SOC code
* Salary is below the required threshold
* Employer is not licensed
* Incorrect or missing CoS
* Wrong or invalid TB test
* Cannot meet English language requirement

---

A simplified version of Skilled Worker for health professionals. ## 2.1 Occupations Eligible

Examples:

* Physiotherapists
* Radiographers
* Paramedics
* Lab technicians (health-related)

## 2.2 Benefits

* Reduced salary threshold
* Reduced visa fees
* **No Immigration Health Surcharge (IHS)**
